citation.article-title: Spirochaeta caldaria sp. nov., a thermophilic bacterium that enhances cellulose degradation by Clostridium thermocellum

p.s: Description of Rhodospirillum salinarum sp. nov.

Cells rod-formed or slightly spiral shaped. Width approx. 0.3 μm, length depending on growth conditions, usually 1-3 μm. Motile by means of a pair of flagella at one end of each cell. The cells multiply by binary fission and contain intracytoplasmic membranes of vesicle type. Photoheterotrophic growth under anaerobic conditions gave bright red colored cultures. On plates, heterotrophic growth gave dark red colonies, at first with pink to white borders. Gram negative. DNA base composition, 68.1 mol % guanine plus cytosine (thermal denaturation), 67.4 mol % (buoyant density). In vivo absorption spectrum shows distinct maxima of bacteriochlorophyll a (380, 595, 800 and 870 nm). Spirilloxanthin is indicated by maximum at 550 nm. Optimum NaCl for phototrophic growth, 12-18%, for aerobic growth, 6-12%. No growth below 2% NaCl. Growth temperature 20-45°C with an optimum at 42°C. Optimal pH 7.5-8.
No growth has been registered on any organic substrates in the complete absence of yeast extract or peptone.
In the presence of a small amount of yeast-peptone extract, addition of lactate or casamino acids stimulated growth.
No growth was registered with sulfide or elemental sulphur as electron donors.
Natural habitat: final crystallization ponds of solar salt production works.
Type strain: ATCC 35394 (American Type Culture Collection, Rockville, Maryland).
